habitat: Grows alone or scattered in woods or urban landscaping areas in spring and summer. Found in North America, Europe, and Oceania.
shortDescription: Small brown lawn mushroom with a fragile, ringed stem. Contains deadly amatoxins causing fatal liver poisoning.
benefitsOrToxicity: Contains amatoxins that are highly toxic to the liver, causing mushroom-related deaths.

identification.cap: 1–2 cm, conic to bell-shaped, becoming convex. Smooth or finely wrinkled, dark orangish-brown centrally.
identification.gills: Narrowly attached, close, whitish becoming brownish.
identification.stem: 20–35 mm long, 2–3 mm thick, fragile, brownish with a persistent whitish ring.
identification.microscopicFeatures: Spores 8–9 x 5–6 µm, ellipsoid, smooth, with a pore. Pleurocystidia not found.

note: Often mistaken for Psilocybe. First described by Peck in 1898 as Pholiota rugosa, transferred to Conocybe by Watling in 1981. Synonyms include Conocybe rugosa.
